<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 675, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 526, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 195, 536, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 235, 526, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 262, 561, 294]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 305, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 339, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 380, 536, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 425, 536, 459]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 467, 628, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 500, 596, 518]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 528, 526, 555]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 530, 587]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 596, 621]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 635, 628, 654]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 667, 518, 700]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 714, 561, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 747, 581, 765]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 775, 536, 810]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
A skier is pulled in a straight line along horizontal ground by a wire attached to a kite, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 210, 740, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 381, 591, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
The mass of the skier is \(89\mathrm{kg}\). The wire is at an angle of \(28^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the skier is shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 460, 670, 675]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 699, 534, 717]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 730, 181, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 730, 890, 749]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 2.2 to determine the distance moved by the skier from time \(t = 0\) to \(t = 5.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 884, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = ....................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 890, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 195, 180, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 195, 589, 214]]<|/det|>

<form>R = .................................................... N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 475, 181, 492]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 475, 920, 524]]<|/det|>

<form>tension = .................................................... N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 900, 213]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 920, 507]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 574, 89]]<|/det|>
The current \(I\) in a metal wire is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 102, 539, 120]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v e\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(v\) is the average drift speed of the free electrons in the wire and \(e\) is the elementary charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 526, 184]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by the symbols \(A\) and \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 173, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>A:</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 196, 920, 240]]<|/det|>
<form>................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 241, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 146, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 670, 291]]<|/det|>
Use the above expression to determine the SI base units of \(e\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 322, 306]]<|/det|>
Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<form>base units .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 144, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 794, 447]]<|/det|>
Two lamps P and Q are connected in series to a battery, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 459, 604, 560]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 580, 532, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 611, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
The radius of the filament wire of lamp P is twice the radius of the filament wire of lamp Q. The filament wires are made of metals with the same value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 311, 675]]<|/det|>
Calculate the ratio

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[258, 683, 740, 701]]<|/det|>
average drift speed of free electrons in filament wire of P

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[258, 698, 735, 717]]<|/det|>
average drift speed of free electrons in filament wire of Q

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<form>ratio = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 892, 920, 910]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A potential difference is applied between two horizontal metal plates that are a distance of \(6.0 \text{mm}\) apart in a vacuum, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 119, 734, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 299, 532, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
The top plate has a potential of \(- 450 \text{V}\) and the bottom plate is earthed. Assume that there is a uniform electric field produced between the plates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 377, 920, 411]]<|/det|>
A radioactive source emits a \(\beta^{- }\) particle that travels through a hole in the bottom plate and along a vertical path until it reaches the top plate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 144, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 424, 180, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 424, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude and the direction of the electric force acting on the \(\beta^{- }\) particle as it moves between the plates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 593, 920, 612]]<|/det|>
<form>magnitude of force = ....................................................... N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 624, 920, 642]]<|/det|>
<form>direction of force ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 640, 920, 658]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 672, 180, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 670, 920, 704]]<|/det|>
Calculate the work done by the electric field on the \(\beta^{- }\) particle for its movement from the bottom plate to the top plate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 826, 920, 844]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 803, 89]]<|/det|>
The \(\beta^{- }\) particle is emitted from the source with a kinetic energy of \(3.4 \times 10^{- 16} \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 604, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed at which the \(\beta^{- }\) particle is emitted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 257, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ............................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[910, 259, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 144, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 599, 306]]<|/det|>
The \(\beta^{- }\) particle is produced by the decay of a neutron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 183, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 320, 752, 338]]<|/det|>
Complete the equation below to represent the decay of the neutron.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 361, 690, 395]]<|/det|>
\[{}_{0}^{1}\mathbf{n}\rightarrow {}_{-1}^{0}\mathbf{\beta}^{-}+\begin{array}{c}{...........}\\{...........}\end{array}+\begin{array}{c}{...........}\\{...........}\end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 386, 920, 403]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 415, 181, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 415, 697, 433]]<|/det|>
State the name of the group (class) of particles that includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 448, 309, 465]]<|/det|>
1. neutrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 510, 331, 527]]<|/det|>
2. \(\beta^{- }\) particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
